Fig 5 Sacrificial template induced Fe-, N-, and S-tridoped hollow carbon sphere as a highly efficient electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction reaction Hyelin An Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft 1 Kyeongseok Min Conceptualization Investigation Writing – original draft 1 Yeeun Lee Methodology Investigation Rin Na Data curation Investigation Sang Eun Shim Writing – review & editing Sung-Hyeon Baeck Conceptualization Supervision Project administration Resources Writing – review & editing ⁎ Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Education and Research Center for Smart Energy Materials and Process, Inha University, Incheon 22212, Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Education and Research Center for Smart Energy Materials and Process Inha University Incheon 22212 Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Education and Research Center for Smart Energy Materials and Process, Inha University, Incheon 22212, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Developing electrocatalysts free from precious metals for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is essential for clean energy storage and conversion systems such as metal-air batteries and fuel cells. Herein, hollow-structured Fe-, N-, and S-tridoped carbon (FeNSC) spheres were synthesized by hydrothermal polymerization of polypyrrole, impregnation of iron species, pyrolysis, and a sulfidation processes. During the synthesis procedure, SiO2 nanospheres were used as self-sacrificial templates to achieve a uniform hollow structure. The electronic structure of the highly active Fe–N site was modified by sulfur dopants with relatively low electronegativity, thus efficiently enhancing ORR kinetics. The hollow-structured FeNSC nanospheres exhibited excellent electrocatalytic performance toward the ORR in an alkaline electrolyte, with a remarkable onset potential (0.971 V vs. RHE) and half-wave potential (0.877 V vs. RHE), even outperforming state-of-the-art Pt/C (0.977 and 0.858 V vs. RHE). Furthermore, the FeNSC hollow spheres showed outstanding electrochemical stability over 100 h and methanol tolerance against commercial Pt/C. The findings of this study provide novel insights for designing precious metal-free electrocatalysts with unique hollow structures and heteroatom-doped carbon for energy storage and conversion. Graphical abstract The hollow-structured Fe-, N-, and S-tridoped carbon sphere (FeNSC) as a highly efficient electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) was synthesized via facile impregnation and pyrolysis strategy assisted by self-sacrificial SiO2 template. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalyst Oxygen reduction reaction Hollow structure Heteroatom doping Fuel cell Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Environmental problems and growing demands for non-renewable energy sources have attracted extensive attention for sustainable energy conversion and storage [1–3]. Metal-air batteries and fuel cells are considered as promising candidates for next-generation energy devices as they have high theoretical energy densities and are environmentally friendly [4–7]. However, the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) restricts the overall efficiency of these energy devices owing to the sluggish kinetics of the four-electron pathway; therefore, the development of efficient electrocatalysts for ORR is essential for reducing the overpotential [8,9]. Although Pt/C is regarded as a state-of-the-art electrocatalyst for the ORR owing to its excellent activity, its high cost, scarcity, and insufficient stability have hindered the large-scale commercialization of metal-air batteries and fuel cells [10–12]. To substitute platinum-based electrocatalysts, researchers have studied non-precious metal-based ORR electrocatalysts, such as transition metal oxides, perovskites, and bimetallic alloys, all of which are low-cost and exhibit high performance and excellent stability [11,13–17]. Among these, transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C, M: Fe, Co, and Ni) electrocatalysts have emerged as promising alternatives because of their reasonable price, tunable surface chemistry, adequate ORR activity, and superior durability [18,19]. The highly conjugated transition metal-nitrogen (M-Nx) in the M-N-C structure induces uneven surface charge distribution, thereby promoting O2 adsorption during the ORR [20–22]. Specifically, previous studies have verified that the Fe‒N‒C electrocatalyst has excellent catalytic activity compared to M-N-C with other central atoms (Cu, Ni, and Co). Therefore, many recent studies have focused on the development of Fe-incorporated nitrogen-doped carbon as an electrocatalyst for ORR [23,24]. Wei et al. prepared a highly effective Fe and N co-doped carbon catalyst using carbon black (XC-72), and it exhibited remarkable ORR performance over the entire pH range [25]. Wang et al. reported molten NaCl-assisted preparation of microporous-rich Fe‒N‒C electrocatalyst for ORR to maximize FeN4 active sites, and this catalyst exhibited an excellent half-wave potential of 0.832 V vs. RHE in an acidic solution [26]. Heteroatom (B, P, and S) doping into the carbon matrix is another strategy that can be used to further improve the ORR performance of M-N-C electrocatalysts [27,28]. Depending on the number or type of heteroatom dopant, the surface structure and electronic properties of carbon-based materials can be changed, thereby enhancing the electrochemical ORR performance. In particular, the sulfur dopants incorporated into the carbon matrix (thiophen-like C‒S‒C structure) play a significant role in lowering the ORR activation energy barrier [29]. The C‒S‒C sites redistribute the electron spin density and decrease electron localization around the Fe centers in the Fe‒N‒C electrocatalysts [30,31]. Therefore, heteroatom doping with both nitrogen and sulfur, which have different atomic sizes and electronegativities, generates abundant defect sites in the carbon matrix and synergistically facilitates ORR activity. Further enhancement of the ORR activity of the electrocatalysts can be expected by enhancing their mass transport properties and surface-to-volume ratios. Recent studies have shown that highly controlled structures of electrocatalysts, such as porous, core-shell, yolk-shell, and hollow structures, significantly influence ORR performance [32,33]. In particular, the 3D hollow carbon structure provides a short diffusion length for reactants and promotes the exposure of electrochemically active sites [34]. Additionally, well-defined hollow structures with interconnected pores and cavities allow deep penetration of electrolyte into the inner active sites, thus remarkably boosting ORR activity. Polymer beads or silica spheres are generally employed as sacrificial templates to obtain a well-defined hollow structure and uniform shell thickness. Colloidal silica is the most attractive candidate as a sacrificial template because of its simple synthesis method at room temperature and easily controllable particle size [35]. Herein, hollow-structured Fe-, N-, and S-tridoped carbon (FeNSC) spheres were synthesized by hydrothermal polymerization of polypyrrole, impregnation of iron species, pyrolysis, and sulfidation processes. During the synthetic procedure, a uniform hollow structure was achieved by the chemical etching of SiO2 templates using an HF solution. Furthermore, the highly active Fe‒N bridge site anchored on the S-doped carbon matrix effectively enhanced the ORR performance. The hollow-structured FeNSC spheres exhibited excellent electrocatalytic performance for the ORR in an alkaline solution, with a remarkable onset potential (0.971 V vs. RHE) and half-wave potential (0.877 V vs. RHE), which are both better than those of state-of-the-art Pt/C (0.977 and 0.858 V vs. RHE). In addition, the FeNSC hollow spheres showed exceptional electrochemical stability over 100 h and methanol tolerance against commercial Pt/C. This study opens a new avenue for designing efficient electrocatalysts with highly controlled hollow structures and heteroatom-doped carbon for the ORR in the research area of energy storage and conversion. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and chemicals Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, C8H20O4Si, 98%), pyrrole monomer (C4H5N, 98%), and ammonium persulfate (APS, H8N2O8S2, 98%) were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich. Hydrogen fluoride HF (49 wt.%) was obtained from Avantor Performance Materials Ltd., India. Ammonia water (NH4OH, 25–29%) was obtained from DUKSAN. Iron (III) chloride (FeCl3, 97%) was obtained from Samchun Co., Korea. Commercial 20 wt.% Pt/C was purchased from Alfa Aesar. All materials were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of core-shell structured SiO2@PPy First, SiO2 nanospheres were synthesized using the modified Stöber method. First, 29 mL ethanol (EtOH), 51 mL deionized (DI) water, and 12.5 mL aqueous ammonia (NH4OH) were mixed to prepare solution A. Thereafter, 8.4 mL TEOS was dispersed in 83 mL EtOH to prepare solution B. Solutions A and B were then mixed under vigorous stirring for 12 h at room temperature. The resultant was washed several times with DI water and ethanol and then dried at 60 °C overnight. The prepared SiO2 nanospheres (0.1 g) were dispersed in 20 mL DI water using an ultrasonicator for 1 h. Next, the pyrrole monomer (0.5 mL) was dispersed in the solution and stirred for 30 min for adsorption of the monomer on the surface of the SiO2 nanospheres. After the solution was poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, APS solution (0.1 g) in 10 mL DI water was added and maintained at 140 °C for 8 h. The obtained product was washed repeatedly with DI water and EtOH using a centrifuge at 6000 rpm. The resulting black sample was denoted as SiO2@PPy. 2.3 Synthesis of hollow-structured FeNSC To impregnate Fe species, the synthesized SiO2@PPy and FeCl3 were dispersed in DI water in a mass ratio of 1:1.2 in a round-bottom flask and stirred for 12 h. Subsequently, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure using a rotary evaporator at 74 °C. The obtained sample was placed in a quartz boat, heated to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min‒1 and maintained for 2 h under an Ar atmosphere to prepare SiO2@Fe/FeNC. The residual inactive metallic Fe species and the silica core were chemically etched using a dilute HF solution. 200 mg SiO2@Fe/FeNC was dispersed in 50 mL DI water using an ultrasonicator for 10 min, and then, 0.5 mL HF (50 wt.%) was injected into the solution. The obtained product was named hollow-structured FeNC. To obtain FeNSC hollow spheres, sulfur powder and FeNC with a mass ratio of 1:2 were placed upstream and of the tube furnace and annealed at 400 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min‒1 for 2 h under Ar flow. For comparison, hollow-structured NSC was also synthesized using the same method, except for the absence of FeCl3. 2.4 Physical characterization of hollow-structured FeNSC Crystal structures of the prepared samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD, RIGAKU D/MAX 2200 V/PC diffractometer, Cu-Kα radiation, λ = 0.154 nm, Inha University Core Facility Center for Sustainable Energy Materials (CFSE) of the Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI)). The detailed morphologies and internal structures of the samples were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Hitachi, S-4300SE) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEOL, JEM2100F). The elemental composition and proportion of the prepared catalysts were assessed using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) combined with TEM. Elemental analysis of N, S, and C was performed using an EA1112 CHNOS elemental analyzer. Confocal micro-Raman spectra of the samples were obtained using a HORIBA LabRAM HR Evolution instrument. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner Halenda (BJH) methods were employed to investigate the specific surface area and pore size distribution using N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K (ASAP 2020). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo Scientific, K-Alpha) was used to analyze the surface chemical states of the elements using monochromatic Al Kα radiation. 2.5 Electrochemical measurements of hollow-structured FeNSC All electrochemical measurements were performed using an electrochemical workstation (WonATech Co., Korea) with a typical three-electrode system comprising a glassy carbon electrode (GCE, diameter = 3 mm) rotating disk electrode (RDE) as the working electrode, a graphite plate as the counter electrode, and Hg/HgO (1 M NaOH filled) as the reference electrode. O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH was used as the electrolyte for ORR measurements. The catalyst ink was prepared as follows: first, 2 mg of the prepared catalyst and 16 μL with a 5 wt.% Nafion ionomer was added to a solution comprising 100 μL isopropyl alcohol and 384 μL DI water. After homogenizing the resulting solution in an ultrasonic bath for 1 h, 5 μL of the catalyst ink was loaded onto the GCE. All measured currents were normalized to the geometrical area of the GCE. Before the electrochemical measurements, to activate the electrocatalysts and to confirm their stable current densities, cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out at a scan rate of 100 mV s‒1 for 30 cycles. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were performed to obtain the ORR polarization curves at 1600 rpm and scan rate of 5 mV s‒1. All obtained potential values were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale using Eq. (1): (1) E R H E = E H g / H g O + 0.0592 × p H + E H g / H g O 0 LSV polarization curves were obtained by varying the rotation rates from 400 to 2025 rpm, and the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equations Eqs. (2) and ((3)) were employed to calculate the electron-transfer number (n). (2) 1 J = 1 J K + 1 J D (3) J D = 0.62 n F D 2 / 3 v − 1 / 6 ω 1 / 2 C O 2 where J, JK , and JD represent the measured, kinetic, and diffusion current densities, respectively; n is the electron-transfer number; F stands for the Faraday constant (96,485 C mol−1); D is the O2 diffusion coefficient in 0.1 M KOH (1.93 × 10−5 cm2 s−1); v is the kinematic viscosity of electrolyte (1.09 × 10−2 cm2 s−1); ω is the angular frequency of RDE (ω = 2 πf/60; f is the rotating speed in rpm; and Co2 is the concentration of O2 in saturated 0.1 M KOH solution (1.2 × 10−6 mol cm−3). Stability of the prepared sample was tested via chronoamperometric (CA) measurements at 1600 rpm and a constant potential of 0.5 V vs. RHE. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthetic procedure of FeNSC hollow spheres The synthetic procedure for the hollow-structured FeNSC electrocatalyst is schematically depicted in Fig. 1 . First, monodispersed SiO2 nanospheres with a diameter of approximately 500 nm were synthesized by the Stöber method through the hydrolysis and condensation of TEOS with ammonia as a base catalyst in aqueous alcoholic conditions. The synthesized SiO2 nanospheres and pyrrole monomers were dispersed in DI water via ultrasonic treatment and vigorous stirring. During this process, pyrrole monomers were easily adsorbed on the surface of the SiO2 nanospheres owing to the electrostatic interactions between the positively charged SiO2 surface and the negatively charged pyrrole monomer [36]. The in situ thermal polymerization of polypyrrole (PPy) was performed via the injection of APS solution as the initiator. Subsequently, ferric ions were impregnated into the as-synthesized core-shell structured SiO2@PPy using a rotary evaporator at 74 °C, followed by pyrolysis at 900 °C for 2 h under an Ar atmosphere to obtain core-shell structured SiO2@Fe/FeNC. To prepare hollow-structured FeNC sphere, residual metallic Fe and SiO2 cores were etched using an HF solution. Finally, sulfur powder and FeNC with a mass ratio of 1:2 were placed upstream and downstream of the tube furnace and annealed at 400 °C for 2 h under an Ar atmosphere to conduct additional S doping into the carbon matrix. 3.2 Physical characterization of FeNSC hollow sphere XRD analysis was conducted at 2θ = 10–90° to compare the crystal structures of SiO2, SiO2@Fe/FeNC, FeNC, and FeNSC, as shown in Fig. S1. A broad peak at approximately 22° is observed in the diffraction patterns of the SiO2 and SiO2@Fe/FeNC samples, indicating the presence of an amorphous SiO2 core [37]. In particular, the prominent peaks at 44.7°, 65.1°, and 82.4° in the XRD pattern of SiO2@Fe/FeNC can be indexed to the (110), (200), and (211) planes, respectively, of cubic-structured metallic Fe (JCPDS# 65–4899). Meanwhile, in the XRD patterns of both FeNC and FeNSC, only two broad peaks at approximately 26° and 44°, assigned to the (002) and (101) planes of carbon, respectively, were observed, suggesting successful etching of residual metallic Fe species and carbonization of polypyrrole [38,39]. The surface morphologies and inner structures of the prepared samples were investigated using SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 2 a and d, monodispersed SiO2 nanoparticles with an average diameter of 500 nm had smooth surface morphologies. After coating the polypyrrole on the SiO2 surface via hydrothermal polymerization, the average diameter of the SiO2@PPy particles was 550 nm with a rough surface morphology (Fig. 2b and e). The SEM images of the FeNSC presented a well-maintained spherical shape after the pyrolysis, etching, and sulfidation processes, suggesting high structural stability (Fig. 2c and f). The TEM images and EDS elemental mapping results of SiO2@Fe/FeNC and FeNSC are presented in Fig. S2 and 1 g. As shown in the Fig. S2, a uniform core-shell structure of SiO2@Fe/FeNC was observed, indicating successful hydrothermal polymerization and carbonization of the polypyrrole shell on the surface of the SiO2 nanospheres. The EDS elemental mapping of SiO2@Fe/FeNC shows a homogeneous distribution of silicon and oxygen in the core and iron, nitrogen, and carbon in the shell. Fig. 2g also confirms the well-defined hollow structure of the FeNSC catalyst with a shell thickness of 50 nm, which is favorable for gas and ion diffusion during the electrochemical reaction, thus increasing the electrocatalytic ORR performance [30]. The crystal structure of FeNSC was investigated by the High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and selected-area electron-diffraction (SAED). As shown in Fig. S3, HRTEM image reveals that the FeNSC is composed of disordered graphitic layers without formation of other impurities. Additionally, the SAED pattern in the inset of Fig. S3 has no significant diffraction spots, demonstrating dispersion of single Fe atoms in carbon matrix without Fe-based nanoparticles or nanoclusters. Moreover, the homogeneous distribution of Fe, N, S, and C throughout the hollow structure was observed by mapping the EDS images. To further examine the effect of the sulfidation temperature of the catalyst, FeNSC catalysts were prepared at different sulfidation temperatures of 400, 500, and 600 °C. As the sulfidation temperature increased, severe surface agglomeration and structural collapse were observed in the FeNSC-600 sample (Fig. S4). Interestingly, as shown in Tables S1 and S2, EDS and EA results revealed that higher sulfidation temperatures resulted in lower sulfur content in FeNSC, which is mainly attributed to the release of sulfur dopants in the carbon lattice under excessive annealing conditions [40]. This result demonstrates that an annealing temperature higher than 400 °C is not suitable for sulfur doping in the carbon shell. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the hollow-structured FeNSC nanospheres were determined by N2 adsorption and desorption measurements at 77 K (Fig. 3 a and b). As shown in Fig. 3a, a distinct hysteresis loop was detected for the FeNSC nanospheres in the relative pressure region of 0.5 to 1.0, with a typical type-IV adsorption/desorption isotherm curve, which confirms the existence of a mesoporous structure in the sample [41]. The calculated specific surface area and average pore size of FeNSC were found to be 388.7 m2 g‒1 and 1.26 nm, respectively. The pore size distribution curve obtained from the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method also revealed that FeNSC mainly comprised micropores and mesopores (Fig. 3b). In principle, such a porous structure with a large specific surface area enhances electrocatalytic ORR activity [42]. The well-organized porous structure of the FeNSC nanospheres can ensure rapid diffusion of oxygen-related species in the electrolyte and the exposure of electrocatalytic active sites [43]. Raman spectroscopy was performed to further investigate the carbon structures of the prepared samples, and the corresponding spectra are shown in Fig. 3c. The two main peaks located at approximately 1345 and 1585 cm‒1 indicate the A1g vibration mode of disordered carbon (D-band) and E2g vibration mode of graphitic carbon (G band) [44]. The intensity ratio of the D-band to the G band (ID/IG) is generally used to determine the degree of defects in carbon-based materials [45]. The ID/IG values for NSC, FeNC, and FeNSC were calculated as 0.978, 0.977, and 1.109, respectively. The highest ID/IG value of the FeNSC among the prepared electrocatalysts demonstrates the most defective carbon structure, which is attributed to the synergistic effect of Fe, N, and S tri-doping into the carbon matrix. The enriched defect sites can modulate the electronic surface properties and optimize the adsorption/desorption energy of oxygen on the FeNSC nanospheres, providing efficient active sites for the ORR [46]. XPS was performed to investigate the surface chemical compositions and bonding configurations of NSC, FeNC, and FeNSC. As shown in Fig. S5a, the full-length XPS profiles represent the co-existence of Fe, N, S, and C in the hollow FeNSC spheres, with atomic percentages of 0.51, 16.45, 1.01, and 82.03, respectively, which is in accordance with the above EDS elemental mapping results. The high-resolution XPS spectrum in Fig. 4 a shows the binding energies of the Fe 2p peaks for the FeNSC nanospheres with satellite peaks at 728.1 and 717.3 eV (denoted as Sat.). The two distinct peaks at 724.0 and 710.9 eV correspond to Fe 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 of Fe2+ state, whereas another two peaks located at 725.8 and 712.7 eV are ascribed to Fe 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 of Fe3+ state [47]. The ionic states of Fe without metallic species indicate the formation of highly coordinated Fe‒Nx sites, which serve as efficient active sites for ORR in alkaline solution [48–50]. The N 1s core level spectrum of FeNSC in Fig. 4b can be deconvoluted into five components at 398.3, 399.2, 400.4, 401.3, and 402.9 eV, corresponding to pyridinic N, Fe‒N bonding, pyrrolic N, graphitic N, and oxidized N, respectively [51]. In the Fe‒N‒C structure, the incorporated nitrogen sites are considered to be the number of active sites for ORR. In particular, In particular, pyridinic N sites act as Lewis base sites with an affinity toward O2 adsorption, thereby promoting ORR activity [19]. Additionally, the Fe‒N bonding manifests the successful formation of highly conjugated Fe‒Nx active sites. As shown in Fig. S6, total proportion of pyridinic N and Fe‒N bonding for FeNSC was found to be 54.42%, which is much higher than those for FeNC (43.48%) and NSC (32.19%), demonstrating the great potential of FeNSC for electrocatalytic ORR activity. In the high-resolution S 2p spectrum (Fig. 4c), two peaks situated at 163.9 and 165.1 eV were attributed to C‒S‒C bonding from 2p2/3 and 2p1/2 [52]. The introduction of sulfur dopants into the carbon skeleton with a thiophene-like structure can withdraw electrons from Fe‒Nx sites, thus reducing the D-band center and lowering the adsorption energies of intermediates during the ORR [31]. The other broad peak located at 168.5 eV is characteristic of sulfate species, which can originate from the unavoidable oxidation of sulfur dopants under ambient temperature and pressure. The high-resolution C 1s spectrum further demonstrates N and S co-doping in the carbon structure (Fig. 4d). The deconvoluted peaks located at 284.6, 284.9, 285.9, and 288.1 eV were assigned to C‒C, C‒S, C‒N, and CO bonds, respectively [53]. Multiple-heteroatom doping is generally an efficient strategy for adjusting the electron structure of the carbon matrix, thereby increasing the interaction between defect sites induced by the incorporation of dopants and adsorbed reaction intermediates [54]. Comparing the XPS results for FeNC and NSC in Fig. S5 shows that Fe, N, S tri-doped hollow carbon spheres were successfully synthesized, which not only provided abundant active sites but also accelerated electron transport for ORR in alkaline solutions. 3.3 Electrochemical measurements of FeNSC hollow sphere The electrocatalytic performances of NSC, FeNC, and FeNSC toward ORR were investigated in a 0.1 M KOH solution. First, CV measurements were performed in N2- and O2-saturated electrolyte within the potential range of 0.2–1.3 V vs. RHE at a scan rate of 50 mV s–1, as shown in Fig. 5 a. No evident cathodic peaks were observed in the CV curves of the N2-saturated electrolyte, exhibiting a quasi-rectangular shape, which originated from the electrical double-layer capacitance (Cdl). The larger quasi-rectangular area of FeNSC compared with those of the NSC and FeNC catalysts suggests the highest electrical double-layer capacitance. The Cdl values calculated from the corresponding CV curves are 19.630, 14.335, and 29.445 mF cm–2 for NSC, FeNC, and FeNSC, respectively. In an O2-saturated electrolyte, FeNSC displayed the most positive cathodic peak at 0.776 V vs. RHE, which was higher than that of NSC (0.739 V) and FeNC (0.634 V), demonstrating the distinct synergistic effect of the introduction of both Fe and S species into N-doped carbon toward the ORR [51,55]. To further evaluate the ORR activities of as-prepared samples, LSV polarization curves were obtained using a standard three-electrode setup at a rotating speed of 1600 rpm with 85% iR-compensation. As presented in Fig. 5b, the hollow-structured FeNSC nanospheres showed a more positive onset potential of 0.971 V and a half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.877 V compared with NSC (0.727 and 0.808 V) and FeNC (0.841 and 0.930 V), which are superior to those of state-of-the-art Pt/C (0.858 and 0.977 V). The limiting current density of FeNSC at 0.5 V vs. RHE was 6.06 mA cm–2, exceeding that of NSC (4.32 mA cm–2), FeNC (5.40 mA cm–2), and commercial Pt/C (5.97 mA cm–2). The obtained E1/2 value and diffusion-limiting current density for the hollow-structured FeNSC nanospheres outperformed previously reported noble metal-free electrocatalysts for ORR in alkaline solutions (Table S3). To confirm the effect of sulfidation temperature on ORR activity, LSV measurements were conducted using FeNSC prepared at different temperature of 400, 500, and 600 °C (Fig. S7). The FeNSC-500 and FeNSC-600 samples showed inferior electrocatalytic ORR performances compared to FeNSC-400, exhibiting E1/2 values of 0.870 and 0.853 V vs. RHE for FeNSC-500 and FeNSC-600, respectively. The decrease in ORR performance along with the increased sulfidation temperature may be due to the structural deterioration and lower amount of sulfur dopants that was observed in SEM, EDS, and EA analysis. To calculate the number of transferred electrons (n) during the electrocatalytic reaction, LSV measurements were conducted at different rotation rates (400–2025 rpm), as shown in Fig. 5c. The Koutecky–Levich (K–L) plot obtained from the LSV curves shows linear correlation between the inverse square root of rotation rate (ω−1/2) and inverse current density (J–1), suggesting first-order kinetics to ORR at the potential range of 0.6–0.8 V vs. RHE (inset of Fig. 5c). Based on the slope of the K–L plots, the average n value of the hollow-structured FeNSC was calculated to be 3.98, which is higher than those of NSC (2.76) and FeNC (3.43), demonstrating the successful electrochemical transformation of O2 into OH– throughout the dominant four-electron process of the ORR under alkaline conditions [56]. To further evaluate the intrinsic catalytic activity and kinetic performance of FeNSC toward the ORR, mass-transport-corrected Tafel plots of the prepared electrocatalysts were obtained from the corresponding LSV curves in the kinetic region, as depicted in Fig. 5d. The Tafel slope of FeNSC (84.6 mV dec–1) was much smaller than that of NSC (132.4 mV dec–1) and FeNC (101.4 mV dec–1), which is also a comparable value to that of Pt/C (75.6 mV dec–1). The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of prepared electrocatalysts were examined to get insight into the enhancement of the ORR activity. The ECSA value is calculated by dividing the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl) by the specific capacitance (Cs). The Cdl value can be obtained by conducting CV measurements in non-faradaic potential region from 1.0 to 1.2 V vs. RHE with various scan rates (Fig. S9). As shown in Fig. S9d, the Cdl values of FeNSC, FeNC, and NSC, which are estimated by plotting the capacitive current densities at 1.1 V vs RHE with respect to scan rates, were found to be 16.63, 14.01, and 7.72 mF cm−2, respectively. Based on the geometrical surface area of electrode (1 cm2) and average specific capacitance (40 μF cm−2), the precise ECSA values of electrocatalysts were summarized in Table S4. E C S A = C d l o f e l e c t r o c a t a l y s t ( m F c m − 2 ) 0.04 ( m F c m − 2 ) The highest ECSA value of FeNSC compared with FeNC and NSC manifests the exposure of abundant active sites for electrochemical reaction, leading to the enhanced catalytic activity for ORR. The outstanding ORR kinetics of the hollow-structured FeNSC nanosphere is mainly attributed to the introduction of efficient Fe–N active sites and electronic surface modulation of additional sulfur doping, thereby facilitating O2 adsorption and dissociation during the electrochemical reaction. The effect of additional sulfur doping into the M-N-C catalyst on the ORR activity was demonstrated using density functional theory (DFT) calculations from previous research [57–59]. The calculated free-energy profiles for the ORR on S-doped and undoped Fe‒N‒C indicate that additional sulfur doping effectively facilitates the reduction of *OH intermediates, which is regarded as the most endothermic and rate-determining step for ORR. This phenomenon is mainly attributed to the charge distribution induced by the S dopant, which has relatively low electronegativity. The S dopants adjacent to the Fe–N sites can donate electrons to the Fe center, thereby reducing the strong coordination between *OH and the active sites [60]. Moreover, the enriched charge on the Fe–N sites promotes chemical adsorption of oxygen species and breakage of OO bonding, which can promote the initiation of the ORR process [61]. Accordingly, the above experimental results and previously reported theoretical calculation results indicate that the incorporation of heteroatoms with low electronegativity can efficiently improve the electrochemical ORR performance of M-N-C catalysts [62,63]. Along with the outstanding electrocatalytic ORR activity, the resistance toward methanol crossover as well as the long-term durability of the electrocatalyst are regarded as essential criteria for the commercialization of fuel cells and metal-air batteries. The methanol tolerance tests for FeNSC and commercial Pt/C were compared using chronoamperometry (CA) measurement at constant potential of 0.5 V vs. RHE, as revealed in Fig. 5e. After the injection of 3 M methanol (10 mL) into the O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at 2000s, the Pt/C catalyst showed a severe decrease in current density, as expected. Meanwhile, there was no significant current decay when the hollow-structured FeNSC nanospheres were used as the ORR catalyst, demonstrating its excellent resistance to methanol crossover and CO poisoning. Owing to the weak methanol adsorption energy on Fe‒Nx sites, oxygen molecules are preferentially adsorbed in FeNSC electrocatalyst, thereby maintaining the electrochemical ORR activity even after the addition of methanol solution [64,65]. To further assess the long-term durability of FeNSC and commercial Pt/C, the CA response was recorded at 1600 rpm and a constant voltage of 0.5 V vs. RHE over continuous operation for 100 h (Fig. 5f). After the stability test for 100 h, the Pt/C catalyst exhibited drastic current loss of 28.3% compared with the initial current density. Surprisingly, the only 4.3% of current decay was observed for the FeNSC catalyst over the 100 h, indicating its outstanding long-term durability under the alkaline conditions. In summary, the remarkably superior ORR performance of FeNSC can be ascribed to the following factors. (1) The introduction and distribution of numerous Fe–N sites in the carbon matrix via simple impregnation and pyrolysis methods serve as highly active sites for ORR in alkaline solution. (2) Successful sulfur doping into the carbon matrix remarkably modifies the electronic charge distribution of adjacent Fe–N sites, thereby reducing the reaction energy barrier of the rate-determining OH* reduction step in the ORR mechanism. (3) The spherical hollow structure with a rough surface morphology induced by the self-sacrificial silica template not only provides a large active surface area and exposure of abundant electrochemical active sites but also reduces the diffusion length for oxygen and electrolytes. Overall, the remarkable ORR activity, long-term stability, and methanol tolerance of the hollow-structured FeNSC nanospheres demonstrated high catalytic performance with all the above-mentioned characteristics. 4 Conclusion In this study, hollow-structured FeNSC nanospheres were successfully synthesized by hydrothermal polymerization, impregnation, and heat treatment. The impregnated iron species and PPy shell coated on the surface of the SiO2 spheres were converted to core-shell structured SiO2@Fe/FeNC after the pyrolysis step. The residual metallic Fe and SiO2 core were chemically etched out using HF solution to form hollow-structured FeNC, followed by heat treatment with sulfur powder to incorporate S dopants into the carbon matrix. The synthesized FeNSC hollow structure exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity for the ORR under alkaline conditions, with a remarkable half-wave potential of 0.877 V vs. RHE, a low Tafel slope of 84.6 mV dec–1, and a high limiting current density of 6.06 mA cm–2, outperforming the state-of-the-art Pt/C catalyst. In addition to this, the FeNSC nanospheres displayed exceptional electrochemical stability over 100 h and methanol tolerance compared with commercial Pt/C. The outstanding ORR performance of FeNSC is mainly attributed to its unique hollow structure, well-defined highly active Fe–N sites, and surface charge modification by additional sulfur doping. coredata.dc:description: Developing electrocatalysts free from precious metals for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is essential for clean energy storage and conversion systems such as metal-air batteries and fuel cells. Herein, hollow-structured Fe-, N-, and S-tridoped carbon (FeNSC) spheres were synthesized by hydrothermal polymerization of polypyrrole, impregnation of iron species, pyrolysis, and a sulfidation processes. During the synthesis procedure, SiO2 nanospheres were used as self-sacrificial templates to achieve a uniform hollow structure. The electronic structure of the highly active Fe–N site was modified by sulfur dopants with relatively low electronegativity, thus efficiently enhancing ORR kinetics. The hollow-structured FeNSC nanospheres exhibited excellent electrocatalytic performance toward the ORR in an alkaline electrolyte, with a remarkable onset potential (0.971 V vs. RHE) and half-wave potential (0.877 V vs. RHE), even outperforming state-of-the-art Pt/C (0.977 and 0.858 V vs. RHE). Furthermore, the FeNSC hollow spheres showed outstanding electrochemical stability over 100 h and methanol tolerance against commercial Pt/C. The findings of this study provide novel insights for designing precious metal-free electrocatalysts with unique hollow structures and heteroatom-doped carbon for energy storage and conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Sacrificial template induced Fe-, N-, and S-tridoped hollow carbon sphere as a highly efficient electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction reaction
